captions: Leaves are simple heart shaped, very thin with long leaf
Amruthaballi traditionally used to manage fevers, infections, and digestive issues
This hearty green climber is known for its ability to boost immunity, detoxify the body
Amruthaballi with very thin long leaf, widely used in Ayurveda
Amruthaballi is a versatile addition to your diet
This herbal plant rich in antioxidants
it improves the metabolic system and flushes the toxins out of the body and helps in reducing cholesterol level
Amruthaballi is considered a blood purifier and supports liver function, aiding in the body's natural detoxification process

metadata.region: tropical and subtropical zones of India and other areas in South and Southeast Asia, including Myanmar and Sri Lanka

captions: Asthma weed is used in the treatment of asthma and several lung related respiratory diseases
It is also consumed in herbal tea form as folk medicine for fevers in the Philippines called (tawa-tawa)
Asthma Weed (Euphorbia hirta Linn.) is an endemic plant species that is rich in phytochemicals
It is often used traditionally for female disorders, particularly for dengue fever and malaria
it also cause  worm infestations in children, dysentery, jaundice, pimples, gonorrhea, digestive problems, and tumors
These leaves are dark green or yellow reddish with purplish markings
its flowers are arranged into dense rounded clusters in the upper leaf forks

metadata.region: originating from the tropical regions of the Americas

captions: A perennial evergreen plant from the grass family with over 1,400 species worldwide
A long stick-like, non-wood plant found mostly in forests and among the fastest-growing plants
Valued in Ayurveda as Vanshalochana for balancing Kapha-Pitta and improving skin, respiratory, and metabolic health
Rich in flavonoids, amino acids, vitamins, and minerals with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and liver-protective benefits
A sustainable and eco-friendly resource used in construction, furniture, flooring, paper, and food
Culturally and medicinally significant across Asia, historically used in China, India, and Japan
Helps manage asthma, cough, and respiratory congestion due to its expectorant property
Supports skin healing and wound care with its anti-bacterial and anti-inflammatory properties

metadata.region: Asia, Africa, and the Americas; thrives in tropical and mountainous climates

captions: Seed of the Areca catechu palm, commonly known as betel nut, supari or areca nut
Contains alkaloids (arecoline etc.), polyphenols, flavonoids and minerals responsible for its effects
Used traditionally in Ayurveda to aid digestion, treat worms & diarrhea, improve oral hygiene and relieve joint pain
Short-term effects: alertness, increased saliva, heightened heart rate, possible dizziness and sweating
Long-term use linked to oral ulcers, gum disease, precancerous lesions, cancers and dependence
Precautions: avoid during pregnancy, with tobacco; risk increases with dose and frequency

metadata.region: Tropical Asia and many tropical regions; widely used in South Asia, Southeast Asia

captions: Tropical evergreen shrub with striking variegated foliage
Leaves mottled in cream, pink, chocolate or yellow over green — decorative and eye-catching
Used traditionally for wounds, ulcers, swelling, constipation, earaches and menstrual disorders
Exhibits anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antidiabetic, antiplaque, oxytocic and anti-implantation effects in studies
Leaves contain saponins and act as mild soap substitute in folk practice
Grows to ~3.5 m, prefers moist well-drained soil, tolerates shade, and responds well to pruning
Propagates easily from cuttings; rooted in ~4-6 weeks

metadata.region: Native to New Guinea; cultivated widely in tropical Asia and tropical gardens

captions: Aromatic rhizome from the ginger family (Zingiberaceae), notably Alpinia galanga (greater galangal)
Rich in polyphenols and antioxidants that combat oxidative stress and may lower LDL and blood sugar
Exhibits anti-inflammatory and analgesic potential; may reduce pain in joint disorders
Has antimicrobial activity against bacteria, fungi, and parasites
Contains galangin, which shows anticancer effects in lab studies
Preliminary evidence suggests support for male fertility (sperm count and motility improvements)
Used widely in Southeast Asian cuisine for its sharp, citrusy flavor; similar but distinct from ginger
Generally safe in food amounts; high-dose use may lead to GI upset, loss of appetite or more serious effects

metadata.region: Native to South and Southeast Asia; used across tropical Asia and in tropical cuisines

captions: Aromatic leaves of *Pelargonium* species, commonly known as geraniums
Vibrant flowers ranging from white to pink to red, characteristic of geranium plants
Essential oil extracted from *Pelargonium graveolens*, known for its therapeutic properties

metadata.region: Native to South Africa; widely cultivated globally
metadata.safety: Generally safe when used appropriately; always dilute essential oils before topical application and consult with a healthcare provider if pregnant, nursing, or on medication.

captions: Shrub or small tree whose leaves yield a reddish-brown dye (lawsone) used for skin, hair, nails, fabrics
Used in mehndi / henna tattoos, as well as hair dyeing and ornamental dyeing
Possesses antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, wound healing and soothing skin properties
Traditional use in skin conditions, burns, rashes, and as a topical cooling agent
Warning: adulterated “black henna” with PPD/heavy metals can cause severe allergic reactions, dermatitis
In individuals with G6PD deficiency, henna may trigger hemolytic anemia
Culturally significant: used in bridal ceremonies, festivals; one of oldest cosmetic practices
Drought-deciduous plant native to Africa/Asia, regenerating after rains

metadata.region: Native to Northern Africa, Western Asia, parts of India and Australia; cultivated widely

captions: One of the largest edible tree fruits (Artocarpus heterophyllus), used in both sweet and savory dishes
Rich in fiber, vitamin C, B vitamins, potassium, magnesium, and antioxidants
Phytochemicals in jackfruit exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and wound-healing effects
May help regulate blood sugar and improve glucose tolerance via unripe fruit and leaf/bark extracts
High potassium and fiber content support heart health by lowering blood pressure and LDL cholesterol
Fiber and prebiotics from flesh and seeds benefit digestion and colon health
Unripe jackfruit is used as a meat substitute; ripe fruit consumed fresh, in jams, desserts; seeds edible when cooked
Caution: potential cross-allergy with latex/birch pollen and high potassium risk in kidney disease

metadata.region: Native to India; now cultivated across tropical Asia, Africa, and parts of Americas

captions: A crisp, juicy cruciferous vegetable with a swollen above-ground stem (bulb) related to cabbage and broccoli
Packed with vitamin C, fiber, potassium, magnesium, and B vitamins — low in calories but high in nutrition
Contains glucosinolates, isothiocyanates, anthocyanins, and carotenoids offering antioxidant and anti-cancer benefits
Supports digestive health, fueling gut bacteria and aiding regular bowel movements
Helps regulate blood sugar and supports metabolic health due to low glycemic index and fiber content
Promotes heart health via potassium, fiber, and antioxidant compounds that support blood pressure and cholesterol levels
Versatile in the kitchen: can be eaten raw, roasted, sautéed, spiralized, or cooked with both bulb and leaves

metadata.region: Originally Europe; cultivated worldwide including Asia and North America

captions: Aromatic tropical grass (Cymbopogon citratus) with lemony aroma, used widely in cooking, teas and aromatherapy
Rich in antioxidants (citral, quercetin, phenolics) that reduce inflammation and oxidative stress
Essential oil and extracts show antibacterial, antifungal and antimicrobial activity against common pathogens
Traditionally helps digestion: relieves bloating, cramps, indigestion, and may protect gastric lining
Acts as mild diuretic helping detoxification and may support blood pressure regulation
Oil and tea used for pain relief, stress reduction, dandruff management, skin health, and anti-inflammatory support
Used in soaps, candles, insect repellents, dishes and beverages for its fresh citrus flavor and scent
Consumption should be moderated; high doses or topical use may cause irritation, and pregnant/kidney patients need caution

metadata.region: Native to Southeast Asia; cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide

captions: Edible and medicinal flower (Calendula officinalis), used in ointments, teas, and extracts
Contains antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds that help reduce oxidative stress and inflammation
Promotes wound healing, scar recovery, and reduces swelling and redness in skin injuries
Antimicrobial, antifungal, and antiviral actions useful for skin, ear canal, and mucous membrane infections
Soothes rashes, eczema, diaper dermatitis, radiation damage, and general skin irritations
Traditional use in digestive support—gastrointestinal inflammation, ulcers, and soothing internal tissues
Has antispasmodic effects relieving muscle cramps, menstrual discomfort, and smooth muscle spasms

metadata.region: Native to southern Europe, now cultivated worldwide in temperate climates

captions: Also known as Kalmegh or ‘King of Bitters’, used for immune stimulation, fever reduction, and antiviral support
Contains andrographolide, diterpenoids, flavonoids, and glycosides which contribute to anti-inflammatory and antioxidant actions
Traditionally used against dengue, malaria, chikungunya and other intermittent fevers
Supports liver health, digestion, gastric and intestinal lining protection via cholagogue and hepatoprotective properties
Exhibits hypoglycemic effects and supports heart health by reducing lipid accumulation and lowering blood pressure
Can help detoxify the blood, reduce post-fever weakness, improve appetite and treat skin disorders
Overdose risks: GI distress, vomiting, anorexia; contraindicated in pregnancy, bleeding disorders, hypotension, ulcers

metadata.region: Native to South and Southeast Asia; widely cultivated in tropical Asia

captions: Globally cultivated Allium cepa containing sulfur compounds and flavonoids with diverse health benefits
Helps modulate metabolic syndrome risk factors: blood sugar, hypertension, lipid levels, and obesity
Quercetin and sulfur compounds confer strong antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, liver & kidney protection
Exhibits antimicrobial action against E. coli, H. pylori, S. aureus and supports gut microbiota via prebiotics
May improve respiratory health by reducing airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness
Shown to have neuroprotective, immune-modulating, and reproductive support benefits in preclinical studies

metadata.region: Native to central Asia; now cultivated worldwide in temperate and subtropical regions

captions: Leaves from *Carica papaya* tree, used traditionally in teas, extracts, and juices for medicinal purposes
Shown in studies to help increase platelet counts and alleviate symptoms in dengue fever patients
Rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds that protect liver health and reduce oxidative stress
Contains papain and proteolytic enzymes that aid digestion, reduce heartburn and bloating
Potential support for blood sugar regulation through pancreatic protection and insulin modulation
Used topically for wound healing, skin health, and antimicrobial protection including acne and fungal infections
In vitro studies suggest papaya leaf extract may inhibit SARS-CoV-2 main proteases—potential antiviral application

metadata.region: Native to tropical Americas; cultivated globally in tropical and subtropical regions

captions: Fruit of *Punica granatum* rich in fibers, vitamins, and powerful polyphenol antioxidants
Contains punicalagins, ellagitannins, anthocyanins, and other compounds that reduce oxidative stress and inflammation
Supports cardiovascular health by lowering blood pressure, reducing arterial plaque, and stabilizing heart tissue
Shows anti-cancer activity, especially in prostate cancer, through inhibition of tumor growth and cell proliferation
May help prevent kidney stones, support urinary health, and promote gut microbiome balance through fiber and polyphenols
Improves exercise endurance, muscle recovery, and may protect brain function via antioxidant, anti-inflammatory effects
Used in skincare for its antimicrobial, anti-aging, and UV-protective properties; may help with acne, hyperpigmentation, and wound healing
Pomegranate peel extract offers strong benefits but more human clinical research is needed for dosage and safety

metadata.region: Native to the Middle East and Mediterranean; cultivated globally in warm climates

captions: Heartwood of *Pterocarpus santalinus* (red sandalwood) used in Ayurveda for its cooling, astringent, and detoxifying properties
Exhibits antioxidant, hepatoprotective, antimicrobial, and anti-inflammatory effects useful for wounds, skin, liver, and ulcers
Traditionally used as a diuretic, expectorant, and astringent to support digestive health, reduce edema, and relieve cough
Used to purify blood, treat gastrointestinal ulcers, dysentery, bilious disorders, and internal heat conditions
Shows antidiabetic and lipid-lowering potential; research suggests anticancer activity against inflammatory mediators
Applied externally to heal wounds, soothe sunburn, acne, pigmentation, control oil, and improve skin complexion

metadata.region: Native to southern India (Eastern Ghats), especially Andhra Pradesh; endangered and regionally restricted
